etymologies: Middle English: probably via Middle Dutch from Old French grenat, from medieval Latin granatus, perhaps from granatum (see pomegranate), because the garnet is similar in color to the pulp of the fruit

definitions: a precious stone consisting of a deep red vitreous silicate mineral
shortDefinitions: precious stone consisting of deep red vitreous silicate mineral

definitions: any of a class of silicate minerals including this, which belong to the cubic system and have the general chemical formula A₃B₂(SiO₄)₃ (A and B being respectively divalent and trivalent metals).
shortDefinitions: any of class of silicate minerals including this, which belong to cubic system
